description: Take a trip to Italy without the airfare; this Toronto neighborhood has maintained all the charm of a small Italian community.

reviews.title: Taste of Little Italy has limited Italian Taste
text: This year there were three good Italian bands and singers that we really enjoyed. They are spread out so that you can walk to which ever one is playing. The only Italian food is at the 3 or 4 Italian restaurants. Only Cafe Diplomatico opens before 1 pm on Sunday and so there are line ups. If you sit on the extended patio you need to pay with cash. Menu is limited but the food is good, but not great. I ordered mussels in red sauce and the waiter kept insisting that the white sauce was better. Thinking that maybe there had been complaints I said ok to the white sauce. It was so spicy hot I didn't eat it and I am used to eating hot food. There were at least two jalepenos sliced into the broth that completely overpowered the delicate mussels. Without the broth or something to dip the bread into, it wasn't much of a lunch.  I noticed that Cafe Diplomatico had street food vendors out the front with things like speducci skewers that were not on the sit down menu. There is little space to sit if you get street food from anywhere. They should have cannolis and biscotti instead of churros, and pasta and meatballs instead of butter chicken. See some Brio instead of juice based drinks
It's worth a short visit and maybe better at night. There are other non Italian places to eat but that sort of defeats the purpose.

reviews.title: worst street festival in toronto.
text: an absolute waste of a summer night. no italian whatsoever. why would you call it the Taste of Little Italy when there is literally nothing to do with Italian culture or restaurants. big miss.

reviews.title: Great Place to Visit and Eat
text: As we toured around Toronto, this was one of our destinations to see. It was everything people talked about in their reviews. So many restaurants to eat and shopping galore. Parking was a big problem since there are so few places on the street. We spent some time walking around to enjoy the atmosphere on a beautiful day.

reviews.title: Had dinner don‚Äôt see much
text: Perhaps I was in the wrong place but I didn‚Äôt see any Italian culture here. Only restaurants. Still nice humble neighborhood.

reviews.title: A welcoming community
text: We spent a week living in Little Italy and loved it. We had a rental house just a short walk from the main area of College St and spent our time having breakfast at the many bakeries or coffee houses and dinner at different restaurants every night. Lots of wonderful fresh fruit and veg shops to pick up some healthy eating everywhere as well. The people are kind and welcoming and I didn't want to leave.

reviews.title: Little Italy festival
text: Not worth going to. It‚Äôs hardly an Italian festival as there are Stalls offering food from all over the world. Actually Italian food was the least being offered that I could see and I walked both sides of the street the length of the festival. You can tell the vibe here from the organizers and the venders is money money money. No free anything being offered. You would of thought the committee that gets together to put this on would be giving away pasta and cheap Italian foods. Pasta by the bag is less than a buck and so is the sauce. Overall I would rate my experience
a C-. Just no Italian vibe going on here other than the one or so desert stand and the old Italian guy singing in the tent.

reviews.title: Worth a visit
text: We visited Little Italy on a humid and lively Saturday night in August and felt there was enough ‚ÄúItaly‚Äù to justify the name - in terms of restaurants, coffee bars and gelato stores. We had a tasty, authentic Italy dinner at La Forchetta (pasta, Montepulciano wine) and delicious creamy ice cream at Dolce. The focal point of Little Italy is College Street - it‚Äôs a pleasant 20-minute stroll through the neighbourhood, and although purists might argue there are numerous other cuisines and cultural influences present, we felt it was definitely worth a visit to sample a taste of Italy üá≠üá∫.

reviews.title: Not too much too see
text: I love the European atmosphere, architecture so little Italy in Toronto is a must-visit destination for me. We went there in the afternoon and to be honest, there were not too many shops opened and there was not much to see. Frankly speaking, I am a bit disappointed and the whole area does not quite make me feel like I am in the Little Italy. My suggestion is to visit other destinations first and if you still have time you could come visit little Italy.

reviews.title: Did I miss something?
text: We love anything dealing with Italy, so the chance to go to Little Italy while we were in Toronto was a huge plus. We walked here along College Street from the subway so we passed through Kensington Market to get here. We did go off a couple couple side streets but truthfully, besides a few Italian restaurants that looked to be a bit higher-end and a gelato place (which was yummy), we saw very little that looked Italian. Maybe we went on the wrong weekend? Maybe we missed what street any vendors or shops were on? But besides getting to walk with my spouse, this part of the trip felt like a bust.

reviews.title: Not so impressed if you know Italy
text: We had a stroll in this place but we're dissapointed because there are not so many Italian shops and the place itself is not as in Italy.  Maybe for someone who is not travelling could be impressive, but for those who know Italy for sure it is a dissapointment.

reviews.title: What a wonderful place to visit!
text: great place to visit, walk thru, have dinner, brunch, or visit the bakery for a pastry and espresso. We wee in Toronto for 2 nights and ate in this area both nights!

reviews.title: Favorite place in Toronto
text: Visit every year and we always make it a point to check out Little Italy. You can still find authentic bakeries and restaurants. Lots of great cafes for people watching.

reviews.title: Nice!
text: Very nice and cozy Italian neighborhood. The only thing is they close early on weekdays, so is difficult to find a spot at night

reviews.title: Beautiful area
text: After Yorkville probably one of the best areas in Toronto. Sure no comparison to the real Italy, but as any other international neighbourhood in Toronto, it is just a nice touch. Several nice bars and restaurants and definitely nice people out, making the night look pleasant.

reviews.title: Felt Welcomed!
text: Stayed in Little Italy, wow close to shops, and good food, enjoyed the freedom and great caf√©s :))
Thanks

reviews.title: Nice place
text: It was nice to be at this place while walking on the college street in Toronto to have good taste as well

reviews.title: Don't Rent Here
text: Having been to Italy, Toronto's little Italy is a dump! The houses are old and tattered and not in the old ancient kind like in Italy, but of the homeless variety. The streets are dirty and quite loud. Yes it might have hip restaurants but it's not a place to rent. Homeless people hang out around the corner stores and it's got a dodgy feel over all. If you want to come to little Italy and check it out then go for it, but as a place to rent and live I will caution you to stay away. There are higher value spots to check out in Toronto.

reviews.title: International but lacked authenticity
text: LITTLE ITALY restaurants with umberellas and canopieslined the street and all looked nice places to cheak out at an afternoon. However it seems a little touristic, i am not sure how autentic this all is.

reviews.title: International flavour.
text: Parts of this neighbourhood really do bring me back to my trip to Italy. GREAT little food shops, and fabulous eateries, some traditional Italian, and some very new and edgy. This is one of Toronto's best examples of ethnic diversity!

reviews.title: Best food ever.
text: Authentic Neapolitan pizza and creamy strong cappuccinos on every corner. How can you complain.
Loads Of cafes and restaurants to choose from. This Is a great area of  Toronto  and well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Great area to vist
text: Great place to get the Italian experience. Many places to eat, drink, or snack. Bring your
appetite. Fun for the whole family or date night.

reviews.title: Don't know what the fuss is about
text: We got the recommendation to go here. We went by bike in the evening, but we didn't think it was special. It's a nice neigbourhood with restaurants and cafe's, but nothing special if you aks me. We find via tripadvisor a nice italian restaurant for dinner and then went home!

reviews.title: Neat place to visit
text: Great neighbourhood full of restaurants, bars and shops. Side streets are quiet residential areas, lots of homes well kept, nicely landscaped. Bonus for us that the weekend we were there it was also "The Taste of Little Italy" and the big Soccer tournament (sorry, I'm not a soccer fan!) - lots of restaurants with giant screen tv's on their patios, patrons dressed in their teams gear - very festive atmosphere, great to see so many people out and about.

reviews.title: Cool Spot
text: There are lots of neat little cafes, bars, shops and the like. The atmosphere is usually frantic but really quite neat.

reviews.title: Primo for dates of all ages, preferences and budgets.
text: I live on the edge of this neighbourhood. I get takeout at least once a week, often a lot more, and it's almost never Italian, though there's great Italian for sure. I walk and ride through here daily, talk to neighbours and businesses in the area and totally love being part of this part of this city.

If you're standing on the street staring at a map or guidebook in Little Italy, chances are good someone will ask you if you need help. If you don't speak English well, chances are someone close by will speak your language.

Despite the name, you'll hear as much or more Portuguese, Chinese, French, Spanish, Hebrew or Korean as you will Italian spoken as you walk along College Street. Every business will greet you in English.

It's mostly about food and drink and more than just Italian, but there's still some key little Italian grocers if you're looking for something specific. Even go into the big Metro chain grocery store and you'll find treats, meats, coffees and so on that cater to those for whom the 'hood is named. There's are a few family clothing stores, record stores, boutique shops, big and small music venues, and all sorts of nice date options.

There's great take out, family and/or fine Italian food in the area and plenty of it. No matter your age, time of day, year or mood, there's GELATO everywhere. Got kids - ask if the place you're at has toppings for their ice cream, sorbet or gelato.

Read up in TripAdvisor for specifics, as reviews on the whole are accurate. Business' come and go, but there's at least one place my dad hung out as a teen and I used to go to that my kid will probably be at eventually with his friends to be loud and fed well (The Dip'), and there are lots of places I went to 20+ years ago that are still there (Kalendar, Sicilian Sidewalk Cafe, Diplimatico, Regina's, Bitondo, Bar Italia, Orbit, College Street Bar, Caledonian).

This neighbourhood is primo for dates of all ages, preferences and budgets. It's a safe neighbourhood and despite a conservative old guard here and there (so-many-churches!) welcoming no matter who you are.

Pubs, Izakayas, take-out of every kind including some good new burger spots, burrito, fish and Middle Eastern places, a couple of really good record stores especially for indie Canadian titles and vinyl, bike stores, etc.. Generally the character of the area is why so many people visit and live here.

Not a lot of hotel options, but for in-home and apartment rentals, this is a great area and if you're visiting Toronto it's reasonably central to a lot of attractions and good for transit. There are a few B&B's but there are more in the Annex, the adjacent neighbourhood just north and east (walk-able).
Give yourself a meal and a couple of hours to visit. If you come during Taste of Little Italy come hungry and take transit.
Neighbourhoods within a 20 minute walk: Kensington Market, The Annex, Trinity Bellwoods, Queen West, Bloor West, Koreatown, China Town (Spadina), University of Toronto, Little Portugal.

reviews.title: Absolute waste of time
text: We went here since we saw reviews and what not. However, this part of Toronto is pretty much exactly as the rest of Toronto.
"Little Italy"? I don't know when this was true, but it must have been long time ago. It's just regular Toronto.
Comparing it to China town, this is a huge difference. China town is quite as much China town as it can be. But little Italy... Save the time.

reviews.title: If you are Italian what would you do
text: Of course you would go to Little Italy if the food does not draw you in the fun of the people and the shops will.

reviews.title: Are we really in Toronto?
text: Once again, an afternoon on a sunny day spent wandering Little Italy. So many restaurants, bars, bakeries and cafes. Every time we come here we feel like we are back in Italy as we were a few summers ago. Full of young people speaking Italian, full of life, and food, and wine. An amazing way to spend some time in Toronto!

reviews.title: Memories of Italy
text: It's a great place to visit .Many shops and restaurants to choose from.
The food is all Italian and delicious.The stores carry items from Italy.Like shoes and jewellery.Cafes to have an espresso and a pastry,Lots of fruit and vegatables stores.
A great way to spend an afternoon.

reviews.title: Trip to Toronto
text: I love to travel, and Toronto is great! It was a little cold out in January but Little Italy is worth being cold.  We found a little place for dinner and it was great!

reviews.title: Great place for a stroll, lunch, dinner, a coffee, cannoli or gelato
text: Great place to take a walk along this bustling street now filled with restaurants, bars, cafes, and a few stores in between.  This street has been transformed from many merchants during the 50's, 60's, 70's and 80's to what was called in a NY magazine in the late 90's as the "hippest street in North America".  Day or night there's action here, from the bars, to gelatos and restaurants.  Enjoy a gelato or the best cannoli at Scicilian Ice Cream on the patio, or sip an espresso at Bar Diplomatico or any of the hundreds of other locations.

reviews.title: Taste of Italy on College St.
text: Last weekend was the CHIN picnic and taste of Italy on College St.  I was not very impressed.  There was no Italian food being showcased, and this was very disappointing. There were no really good vendors.  We bought what was supposed to be lemonade at one stand for $4. It was actually warm punch. Then we got a funnel cake which is definitely NOT Italian.  We had to go to San Francisco sandwiches to get Italian food.

reviews.title: gread area with great food
text: We went there when they had a festival (taste of italy I guess). It was very busy with lots of food and trink possibilities. but what I really like was, that all the cute restaurants had big outdoor seating areas.
I would come to little italy also if there is not a festival. great vibe!

reviews.title: Love Little Italy!!!!
text: Everytime we go to Toronto we have to stop in out favorite section of Little Italy.  Love the shopping and food.  It kind of reminds of us of being in Italy.

reviews.title: Eclectic restaurants
text: We had heard about this restaurant/bar Pinky's which is rather hard to find especially since they do not have any signage.  It looks like a renovated home with a large bar area, small outdoor seating and a few crowded tables on the enclosed front porch.  Beware of the very steep and small steps going down to the restroom.  We ordered mango papaya salad which had a unique taste, not sure if that is a compliment or not.  The Pho beef dip you dip I dip sandwich was average in taste.  I ordered the Saigon rock cocktail and my husband ordered the Foco Loco.  My cocktail didn't have much taste.  I think the owners are trying hard to be a trendy cocktail bar but it fell short.

Another place we tried in the area was the Her Father‚Äôs Cider Bar and Kitchen on Harbord Street. They have only been open for a year and they are really trying hard to please.  We sat on the patio and did a three cider tasting.  The server asked what we liked and gave us spot on recommendations.  These ciders I believe are mostly local.  Highly recommend.
Fun and interesting area to visit!!!

reviews.title: Nice area with Italian touch and great restaurants
text: Very nice area and worth visiting for ! Nice meal or coffee or desert. A walk will reveal a number or restaurants and coffee  places with a great 'Italian' touch.

reviews.title: Vibrant Atmosphere
text: Great to walk around and feel the Toronto's multicultural feeling. There are many options of good restaurants, tradicional italians restaurants, cafes, stores and much more...  I recommend visiting when in Toronto.

reviews.title: Sedate
text: One of the more obvious neighbourhoods to visit in Toronto, and one which draws a lot of tourists.  Those who come are getting a bit of Toronto's multicultural aspect, but they are not venturing too far into the wide varieties available.  Because of that it is a bit sedate, but it is interesting to visit nonetheless.

reviews.title: Great to Explore
text: This was one of my favourite areas to explore when I stayed in Toronto. There are many interesting cafes, restaurants, stores, and more.

reviews.title: Great food!
text: Love coming here to try new restaurants! Have had some great meals in very friendly reasonable priced restaurants!!!
